item.title: The eco-conscious GROHE smart water system is gaining traction in Asia
item.description: Source: GROHE. The GROHE Blue system in action. GROHE Blue, a smart water system, has become increasingly popular in Asia since a May 2014 study revealed its smaller carbon footprint compared to bottled mineral water. The study estimated that the GROHE Blue system generates 17.96 g CO2-eq/liter, significantly less than the 70 to 600 g CO2-eq/liter produced by bottled mineral water. The variation in bottled water emissions is linked to packaging and origin.

item.title: Guests are invited by Jumeirah Dhevanafushi to discover the house reef
item.description: Source: Jumeirah Group. Underwater view of a reef. Jumeirah Dhevanafushi, a secluded resort at the southernmost point of the Maldives, has launched a new “Underwater Snorkeling Adventure” experience, allowing guests to explore the resort’s own reef. This package provides a guided opportunity to discover some of the planet’s most impressive coral reefs. Led by Jumeirah Dhevanafushi’s resident marine biologist, guests can explore the reefs surrounding the heart-shaped Meradhoo island, situated on the Gaafu Alifu Atoll.

item.title: The Landmark Mandarin Oriental Hong Kong has become more environmentally friendly than ever
item.description: The Landmark Mandarin Oriental, Hong Kong is implementing environmentally friendly practices to offer guests sustainable luxury, including producing its own eco-friendly water and starting a rooftop garden. The hotel is the first in Hong Kong to work with Nordaq FRESH, a Swedish company, to provide filtered and purified water in reusable glass bottles. This system reduces plastic waste and carbon emissions associated with traditional bottled water. Guests can also refill BPA-free bottles at the hotel.
